CASE 100:
PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE OF ILLNESS
I was a final-year medical student when I was diagnosed with Hodgkin’s lymphoma. In the
space of 3 weeks I went from initial presentation at the general practitioner to disease diagno-
sis, including grading and staging. Pretty impressive, considering this involved going for two
consultations (one with a hospital specialist), a blood test, chest X-ray, computed tomography
(CT) scan, fine needle aspiration and biopsy under general anaesthetic. My world had been
turned upside down.
Looking back, the majority of those 3 weeks are a hazy memory. However, my first consulta-
tion with the hospital specialist remains in my head, but for all the wrong reasons. Initially
there were no introductions, which meant I had no idea who anyone was. I remember there
being another person in the room besides the doctor, my mother and myself. I assumed at
the time that she was a student nurse, but this is pure supposition based on my own experi-
ences as a student in outpatient clinics. I certainly was not asked whether I minded her being
present and she did not say or do anything to indicate that her being there was necessary. The
consultant appeared in a hurry and spent most of the consultation speaking to my mother
about everything that had happened, despite the fact that at 23, I was not only the patient, but
also a competent adult (and nearly qualified medical professional!).
The worst thing about the consultation was the provisional diagnosis. It was not broken to me
in the way I would have expected. The consultant asked me what I thought was wrong with
me. By that point, most differentials had been ruled out; the only one left was Hodgkin’s, yet
still I thought I was just being a hypochondriac. I made my suggestion and the consultant
responded, but not with the answer I’d been expecting: ‘Yes, I think it is Hodgkin’s too’. From
that point on, the rest of that consultation is a blur. I can’t remember any of the other informa-
tion I was given; my mind had gone into overdrive and the only thing I could think was that I
had cancer and might die. A week later, after the diagnosis had been confirmed histologically,
I went for CT staging. Again, I found this a terrifying experience. I was scared it might show
the cancer had already metastasised, but also of having the scan itself. Nobody had explained
the procedure to me – that I would need to be cannulated and have intravenous contrast
injected. By the time I got into the CT scanner, I was hysterically upset. A form was thrust
at me, which I was asked to sign. To this day I have no idea what I signed for, whether it was
to consent to the scan, confirm I didn’t have any allergies to iodine/ shellfish or to confirm
I wasn’t pregnant.
Despite having spent 2 years on hospital ward as a student, being an inpatient while I received
chemotherapy was a completely different experience. It made me really think about what my
own patients must have been going through. There are things that you don’t appreciate as
a student (and perhaps even as a junior doctor). Privacy was a big problem. I was paranoid
about sleeping since everyone would see me and possibly hear me snore. I was constantly
tired as the nurses are always coming to do observations or give drugs. Machines bleeping
constantly were also a huge annoyance! I was also always asked about how I was feeling and
about my intimate bodily functions in front of an entire ward of patients and relatives. It was
also very lonely being a patient; I would see doctors on their rounds for less than 10 minutes
and then speak to no one till visiting hours in the afternoon.
I spent 6 months as a patient, and thankfully now I’m a doctor. But my experience was
more valuable than any lectures or clinics, since it made me think a lot about the way we treat
our patients.
Questions
• Should I have been treated quicker just because I am a medical professional?
• Should the consultant have assumed I knew what all the investigations and treat-
ments involved?
• Is informed consent ever possible when a patient is scared? Or in pain? Or in emer-
gency situations?

10 years later … An update
Ten years on and I still reflect on my own personal experience as a patient. I have no doubt
that it strongly influenced my career choice, as I now specialie in palliative medicine. I rec-
ognise and accept that unfortunately, despite our best efforts as medical professionals, some-
times patients die. In a strange way, I think being forced to confront my own mortality has
enabled me to reconcile the fact that patients die too. Being able to ease patients’ suffering
and support them and their families at such a difficult time is both rewarding and extremely
humbling.
What I learnt through personal experience is echoed time after time by the patients I care for.
Patients value honesty and clear and timely communication from the medical team. Lack of
information leads to a sense of loss of control and a negative patient experience. In any medi-
cal condition, the patient has already lost a degree of control, so anything a doctor can do to
improve that perception is welcomed by patients.
Sometimes ‘being alongside’ the patient is enough. You may not have all the answers and you
may not be able to solve their problem or cure their illness, but being there for the patient and
listening to them goes a very long way, and often doesn’t take up as much of your time as you
think it will.
Kindness is one of the most valuable clinical skills you have. Patients appreciate empathy; if
you treat every patient as you would wish a close relative to be treated, then it’s difficult to go
far wrong.
One of the biggest lessons I’ve learnt is that the human spirit is amazing. Even in the face
of adversity, people can show great strength and resilience. Patients can teach us a lot, not
just about medicine, but also about life itself. As health professionals, we are very privileged
indeed to be able to do the job we do.

data.vignette: A 23-year-old with newly biopsied Hodgkin’s lymphoma is admitted to start first-line chemotherapy. A staging CT with IV contrast is scheduled this afternoon, and chemotherapy is planned for tomorrow morning if staging is completed. In clinic she was quiet while her mother answered most questions. Today she is tearful and says she cannot take in more information. She asks you to “just do what you think is best” and to explain things to her mother instead. The regimen carries short-term toxicities and could affect fertility, and the CT contrast requires screening for prior reactions and pregnancy risk. A nurse asks whether a rotating trainee may observe your consent discussion. Hospital policy allows either proceeding with standard consent now or delaying treatment briefly to allow a longer, calmer consent process.
data.choice_1: Proceed with CT and chemotherapy using brief consent with her mother present.
data.choice_2: Delay staging and chemotherapy to obtain private, detailed consent directly from the patient.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make the orders concrete and mutually exclusive. For example: Choice 1: 'Document that the patient has decision-making capacity and explicitly authorizes her mother to be present; obtain same-day chemo consent using a shortened script focused on key risks (including fertility and pregnancy testing) and proceed with CT today and chemo tomorrow.' Choice 2: 'Postpone CT and first chemo by 24–48 hours; arrange a private consent conversation with an interpreter/advocate as needed; revisit consent once the patient is calmer, then reschedule CT/chemo.' Remove or separately specify the trainee-observer decision so the binary choice stays focused.

key_information.suggested_changes: Clarify essential missing facts that determine whether Choice 1 is even permissible: (1) confirm she is an adult with intact decision-making capacity; (2) whether she is asking to delegate decision-making vs refusing information; (3) whether she explicitly consents to sharing details with her mother and having her present; (4) whether a pregnancy test is pending/required before contrast/chemo; (5) how long the delay would be (e.g., 24–48 hours) and the practical consequences (loss of inpatient chemo slot, need to reauthorize imaging). Remove or relocate the trainee observation detail unless it directly changes the consent/privacy dilemma.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a sentence establishing legal permissibility for both paths in the implied jurisdiction. For example: 'She is judged to have decision-making capacity. Hospital policy permits patients to delegate information-sharing to a family member, but consent for chemotherapy and contrast must still come from the patient; she may also request a private discussion without family present.' Then ensure Choice 1 states the patient consents to mother’s presence and confidentiality waiver; otherwise it risks being clearly noncompliant with adult consent/privacy laws.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Reduce asymmetry by making the costs of delaying more concrete and realistic without claiming worse outcomes: specify that postponing by 24–48 hours could mean losing the scheduled inpatient chemo start, requiring discharge and re-admission, or delaying fertility preservation referral/port placement logistics; alternatively, specify that proceeding now risks the patient later feeling coerced or uninformed and could damage therapeutic trust. Ensure both options are defensible rather than 'good consent' vs 'bad consent'.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the conflict unavoidable and ethically grounded by clarifying the patient’s decision-making capacity and preferences: state whether she is competent but overwhelmed vs possibly lacking capacity due to acute distress. If competent, specify that she explicitly declines to discuss details now but does NOT authorize her mother as surrogate/healthcare proxy, and that she requests the physician decide—forcing a tension between respecting her present wish for minimal information and ensuring informed consent for fertility-impacting chemo and pregnancy/contrast screening. Alternatively, if she lacks capacity, state that and indicate the mother is the legal surrogate; then rewrite Choice 2 to be about waiting for the patient to regain capacity rather than ‘private consent.’

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Stabilize the ethical meaning of each option by tightening wording so small framing edits won’t flip the interpretation. For Choice 1, specify whether consent is obtained from the patient (with mother present) vs from the mother; avoid implying improper surrogate consent. For Choice 2, specify the delay length and what harms it plausibly entails (e.g., loss of treatment slot, progression risk, worsening symptoms) so it is not simply ‘more ethical consent.’ Also remove the trainee-observer detail or explicitly link it to privacy/pressure so it consistently affects the same value dimension.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about who is consenting and what is permissible: clarify whether the patient is an adult with full capacity, whether the mother has any legal authority, and whether the patient consents to involving her mother. Clarify what ‘brief consent’ includes (e.g., confirmation of pregnancy status, contrast reaction history, fertility counseling options). Without these, graders may disagree whether this is an autonomy/privacy case, a capacity/surrogacy case, or simply inadequate informed consent.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Increase balance by giving Choice 1 a defensible ethical upside beyond convenience and making Choice 2 carry a real moral cost beyond delay. Add concrete but qualitative stakes of delaying (e.g., team has a narrow inpatient window; delaying means discharge and weeks-long outpatient wait, increased anxiety/uncertainty, or risk of worsening B symptoms/airway compromise). Also acknowledge that pressing for private detailed consent now could cause psychological harm, overwhelm, and potential disengagement from care. Conversely, make Choice 1 ethically costly by emphasizing irreversible fertility implications and that CT contrast/pregnancy screening requires direct patient confirmation; proceeding risks violating confidentiality and undermining her agency.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove language that frames the patient as incapable or manipulative (e.g., “cannot take in more information”). Replace with neutral clinical descriptions such as “reports feeling overwhelmed and requests you lead decisions today.” Clarify mother’s role without implying default surrogate authority (e.g., “mother present at bedside; patient requests her participation”). Avoid wording that makes one option sound more respectful by default (e.g., “private, detailed consent”). Use parallel, neutral descriptors for both options.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify the decision-forcing timeline and what ‘delay’ entails (hours vs days) and whether delay risks missing the planned chemotherapy start. Specify whether the patient has decision-making capacity and whether she is requesting delegated decision-making vs simply support. Clarify whether consent is needed for chemotherapy initiation, for CT contrast, or both. Remove or tighten extraneous elements (e.g., trainee observer) unless it directly drives the dilemma.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and neutralize choices to 10–15 words, avoid implementation details and loaded modifiers. Example: Choice 1: “Proceed today with CT contrast and start chemotherapy tomorrow with standard consent.” Choice 2: “Postpone staging and chemotherapy briefly to obtain patient-led consent in a separate visit.” Ensure both choices mention the same core actions (CT/chemo timing) and omit ‘brief,’ ‘private,’ and ‘detailed.’

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make Choice 1 ethically/legally defensible by clarifying that the patient has decision-making capacity and explicitly requests a delegated/limited-information consent process with her mother present (e.g., she asks you to explain details to her mother, wants her mother to help her decide, and is willing to sign after a brief explanation). Add that delaying chemotherapy by 24–48 hours may worsen symptoms/complicate scheduling (without quantifying), so Choice 2 carries real clinical and emotional cost. Remove wording that implies the patient is incapable (“cannot take in more information”) or replace with “feels overwhelmed but can answer questions and understands the basics,” so the ‘right’ answer is less obvious.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Eliminate obvious middle-ground options by tightening the forcing constraints and decision framing. For example: state that CT and chemotherapy must occur on this admission because an inpatient chemo slot and imaging slot are available only today/tomorrow, and rescheduling would push treatment back weeks; also state that fertility preservation consult cannot be arranged before the chemo start time. Then define the binary as: (A) proceed tomorrow with a streamlined consent reflecting the patient’s request for maternal involvement vs (B) cancel tomorrow’s chemo slot to ensure a private, extended consent session with the patient alone. Alternatively, explicitly rule out partial deferral (e.g., cannot do CT today and delay chemo) by stating the protocol requires same-day staging review to release the chemo order, and imaging will be canceled if chemo is not confirmed.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 1 conflicts with standard informed-consent expectations for an adult: a mother generally cannot provide consent unless the patient lacks capacity or has formally designated a surrogate. Revise the vignette to create a genuine gray zone by adding one of: (1) the patient is capacitated and explicitly authorizes her mother to receive information and participate, requesting ‘limited disclosure’ to herself; or (2) the patient’s capacity is borderline/fluctuating (severe anxiety/panic, sedating meds) and there is uncertainty about whether she meets capacity for high-stakes chemo consent right now, but delaying has meaningful consequences. Also specify that hospital policy permits either approach under these circumstances and that there is no clear legal requirement in this institution about refusing a patient’s request to delegate information to family, provided minimal elements are reviewed with the patient and documented.

data.vignette: A 23-year-old with newly biopsied Hodgkin’s lymphoma is admitted to start first-line chemotherapy. A staging CT with IV contrast is booked for this afternoon. Chemotherapy is scheduled for tomorrow morning, and the order cannot be released until staging is reviewed; if tomorrow’s inpatient start is canceled, the next available start may be weeks away and could require discharge and later re-admission. She is oriented and able to explain her diagnosis and the purpose of treatment, but she says she feels overwhelmed and does not want a long discussion today. She asks you to give the details to her mother, who is at the bedside, and says she wants her mother’s help deciding. Consent must still come from her, and she must answer questions about pregnancy risk and prior contrast reactions. The regimen can affect fertility and has significant short-term toxicities. Hospital policy confirms that either proceeding with patient-authorized family involvement or postponing briefly for a separate discussion is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Proceed with CT today and chemotherapy tomorrow after streamlined consent with her mother present.
data.choice_2: Postpone CT and chemotherapy by 24–48 hours for an extended patient-only consent discussion.

data.vignette: A 23-year-old with newly biopsied Hodgkin’s lymphoma is admitted to start first-line chemotherapy. A staging CT with IV contrast is booked for this afternoon. Chemotherapy is scheduled for tomorrow morning, and the order cannot be released until staging is reviewed; if tomorrow’s inpatient start is canceled, the next available start may be weeks away and could require discharge and later re-admission. She is oriented and able to explain her diagnosis and the purpose of treatment, but she says she feels overwhelmed and does not want a long discussion today. She asks you to give the details to her mother, who is at the bedside, and says she wants her mother’s help deciding. Consent must still come from her, and she must answer questions about pregnancy risk and prior contrast reactions. The regimen can affect fertility and has significant short-term toxicities. Hospital policy confirms that either proceeding with patient-authorized family involvement or postponing briefly for a separate discussion is legally permissible.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with CT today and chemotherapy tomorrow after streamlined consent with her mother present.

choice_2.choice: Postpone CT and chemotherapy by 24–48 hours for an extended patient-only consent discussion.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add an explicit line that the patient either (a) consents to proceed today after a brief explanation, or (b) requests to delay until she can review risks herself (and whether she agrees to mother’s involvement), so the autonomy tradeoff between the two options is unambiguous.

Add a clause that a 24–48h delay would meaningfully reduce her chance of cure (e.g., rapidly progressive symptoms/oncology notes that any delay increases risk), or alternatively add that postponing allows time-sensitive fertility preservation or safer counseling that would significantly improve her overall well-being.

Add one clause quantifying harm from delay (e.g., "if chemo is not started tomorrow, onc expects a weeks-long delay that could worsen cure odds") and one clause quantifying harm from streamlined consent (e.g., "she cannot recall the fertility/teratogenic risks today and might accept chemo without understanding high-risk consequences").

Add a clause stating that inpatient chemo start slots/bed-days are scarce (e.g., “the unit has a waitlist and holding her bed for an extra 1–2 days would displace another patient”) and/or that rescheduling CT would push another urgent case back, making the justice/resource-allocation tradeoff explicit.

data.vignette: A 23-year-old with newly biopsied Hodgkin’s lymphoma is admitted to start first-line chemotherapy. A staging CT with IV contrast is scheduled for this afternoon. Chemotherapy is scheduled for tomorrow morning, and the order cannot be released until staging is reviewed. If tomorrow’s inpatient start is missed, the next available start may be weeks away and could require discharge and later re-admission. She is oriented and can explain her diagnosis and the purpose of treatment. She feels overwhelmed and does not want a long discussion today. After a brief explanation, she says she wants to proceed on schedule and authorizes you to review details with her mother at the bedside. She cannot clearly restate the fertility and pregnancy risks today. Consent must still come from her, and she must answer questions about pregnancy risk and prior contrast reactions. Oncology notes that avoidable delay could allow progression. CT slots, chemo start slots, and bed-days are limited, and prolonging her stay may displace another patient.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with CT today and chemotherapy tomorrow after streamlined consent with her mother present.

choice_2.choice: Postpone CT and chemotherapy by 24–48 hours for an extended patient-only consent discussion.
